title.value: Maximum State Entropy Exploration using Predecessor and Successor Representations
title.justification: This is the exact title as presented in the document.
title.quote: Maximum State Entropy Exploration using Predecessor and Successor Representations

extractions.description: The paper presents ηψ-Learning, an algorithm designed to improve exploration efficiency within reinforcement learning by combining predecessor and successor representations to maximize the state visitation distribution entropy of a single finite-length trajectory.

type.justification: The paper focuses on the proposal and evaluation of a new algorithm (ηψ-Learning) for reinforcement learning, emphasizing theoretical contributions such as combining predecessor and successor representations.
type.quote: In this work, we present ηψ-Learning, an algorithm to learn an exploration policy that methodically searches through a task.

name.justification: The research is focused on advancing techniques within reinforcement learning, a subfield of deep learning, through the development of a novel exploration algorithm.
name.quote: This study of developing exploration behaviors in reinforcement learning is guided by a fundamental curiosity about the nature of autonomous learning.

name.justification: The paper explicitly deals with solving problems in reinforcement learning by introducing ηψ-Learning.
name.quote: The domain of exploration in Reinforcement Learning (RL) focuses on discovering an agent’s environment via intrinsic motivation to accelerate learning optimal policies.

name.justification: ηψ-Learning is the main model introduced and evaluated in this study to enhance exploration efficiency.
name.quote: In this work, we propose ηψ-Learning, an algorithm to compute an exploration strategy that methodically explores within a single finite-length trajectory

name.justification: RLHive was used to implement the proposed method ηψ-Learning and to conduct the experiments.
name.quote: The implementation of the proposed method was done using the RLHive (Patil et al., 2023) library.
